abstract.p: Pittsburgh Penguins play Ottawa Senators to 3-3 tie; roundup of other NHL results (S)

block.p: PENGUINS 3, SENATORS 3: Martin Straka scored with 22 seconds left in regulation to lift the Pittsburgh Penguins to a tie with Ottawa.
Straka took a pass from Jaromir Jagr, after a failed clearing attempt by the Senators, and beat goalie Jani Hurme to complete the Penguins' comeback from a three-goal, third-period deficit.
PENGUINS 3, SENATORS 3: Martin Straka scored with 22 seconds left in regulation to lift the Pittsburgh Penguins to a tie with Ottawa.
Straka took a pass from Jaromir Jagr, after a failed clearing attempt by the Senators, and beat goalie Jani Hurme to complete the Penguins' comeback from a three-goal, third-period deficit.
Jagr and Alexei Kovalev also scored for Pittsburgh.

Rookie Martin Havlat, Magnus Arvedson and Alexei Yashin scored for Ottawa, which had its four-game winning streak stopped. The Senators (4-0-2) managed to set a franchise record for best start to a season, beating last year's mark of 4-1-1.
CANADIENS 3, FLYERS 3: Oleg Petrov scored with 3:13 left in regulation as the Montreal Canadiens earned a tie with Philadelphia.
The Flyers, an Eastern Conference finalist last year are winless in six games.
Petrov skated from the right corner and fired the puck high over the glove side of Philadelphia goalie Roman Cechmanek.
PREDATORS 2, RED WINGS 1, OT: Cliff Ronning's goal 1:51 into overtime gave the surprising Nashville Predators a victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
Sergei Fedorov forced overtime when he scored Detroit's only goal with just 3.4 seconds left in regulation.
But Ronning took advantage of a collision between Detroit goalie Manny Legace and defenseman Larry Murphy at the right of the Red Wings net and put a shot between Legace's glove and the right post.
BLUES 7, KINGS 1: Roman Turek stopped 17 shots and six St. Louis players scored as the Blues beat the Los Angeles Kings.
Turek and the Blues shut down the Kings, who entered as the N.H.L.'s highest-scoring team with 29 goals in their first seven games.
MAPLE LEAFS 4, OILERS 1: Mats Sundin had two goals and an assist to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs over the Edmonton Oilers.
Curtis Joseph stopped 18 shots and has won all seven games he has played against his former team since joining the Leafs in the 1998-99 season.
